title: Stage 2 Registered Report: Anomalous perception in a Ganzfeld condition - A meta-analysis of more than 40 years investigation
citation: Meta-analysis of 113 studies (1974-2020) reports small positive effect (~0.08) with moderator effects and bias checks.
abstract: Large registered-report synthesis finding a small but nonzero overall effect in Ganzfeld databases and stronger effects in selected participants.

title: Meta-analysis of free-response studies, 1992-2008: assessing the noise reduction model in parapsychology
citation: Meta-analysis reports positive effects in ganzfeld and some noise-reduction paradigms.
abstract: Influential synthesis suggesting positive free-response effects but later challenged on randomization and robustness grounds.

title: Meta-analysis that conceals more than it reveals: comment on Storm et al. (2010)
citation: Critical commentary arguing evidence remains unpersuasive absent independently replicable results.
abstract: Methodological critique emphasizing that meta-analytic significance alone is insufficient without robust independent replication.

title: Feeling the future: experimental evidence for anomalous retroactive influences on cognition and affect
publication: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology
citation: Nine experiments reported mean effect size d=0.22 for retroactive influence claims.
abstract: Landmark controversial paper reporting retroactive facilitation effects and motivating large-scale replication efforts.

title: Correcting the past: failures to replicate ψ
publication: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology
citation: Seven replication studies and follow-up meta-analysis reported average effect d=0.04, not different from zero.
abstract: High-powered replication program that failed to reproduce key retroactive facilitation findings from Bem (2011).

title: Why psychologists must change the way they analyze their data: the case of psi
publication: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology
citation: Bayesian reanalysis argues evidence in Bem's data is weak to nonexistent.
abstract: Statistical critique highlighting exploratory flexibility and arguing that one-sided p-values overstated evidential strength.

title: A Bayes factor meta-analysis of Bem's ESP claim
citation: Bayesian assessment across experiments; interpretation differs from both strong-pro and strong-con readings.
abstract: Meta-analytic Bayes factor approach showing how prior choices and aggregation strategy materially alter inference strength.

title: Raising the value of research studies in psychological science by increasing the credibility of research reports: the transparent Psi project
citation: Multi-lab transparent replication of Bem Experiment 1 found 49.89% hits vs 50% chance.
abstract: Demonstrates an intensive transparency protocol and reports null replication for the flagship Bem task.

title: Stage 1 Registered Report: Anomalous perception in a Ganzfeld condition - A meta-analysis of more than 40 years investigation
citation: Pre-registered protocol and analysis plan for long-horizon Ganzfeld synthesis.
abstract: Protocol-first phase that improves auditability of inclusion criteria and analyses before final synthesis.

title: Predictive physiological anticipation preceding seemingly unpredictable stimuli: a meta-analysis
citation: Meta-analysis of 26 reports suggests pre-stimulus physiological differences before random events.
abstract: Frequently cited presentiment synthesis reporting anomalous anticipatory physiological effects.

title: We should have seen this coming
citation: Editorial critique of presentiment analyses emphasizing expectation, trial-order and preprocessing artifacts.
abstract: Argues that extraordinary temporal claims require stronger controls and direct tests of conventional artifact explanations.

title: Examining psychokinesis: the interaction of human intention with random number generators--a meta-analysis
citation: 380 RNG studies showed tiny overall effect with heterogeneity and small-study patterns consistent with bias.
abstract: Classic RNG-PK synthesis often interpreted as evidence of weak effects but strong vulnerability to publication and selection bias.

title: Loophole-free Bell inequality violation using electron spins separated by 1.3 kilometres
citation: Loophole-free Bell test rejected local realism under strict conditions.
abstract: Confirms nonlocal quantum correlations while not establishing controllable faster-than-light communication channels.

title: Quantum field theory cannot provide faster-than-light communication
citation: Formal argument that QFT cannot be used for superluminal signaling.
abstract: Theoretical no-signaling constraint often cited to distinguish correlation nonlocality from actionable communication.

title: Gravitational Waves and Gamma-rays from a Binary Neutron Star Merger: GW170817 and GRB 170817A
citation: Joint detection constrains speed difference between gravity and light to around 10^-15.
abstract: Multi-messenger constraints substantially reduce plausibility of many superluminal or exotic carrier models.

title: AWAreness during REsuscitation - II: A multi-center study of consciousness and awareness in cardiac arrest
citation: In-hospital arm: no correct visual target identifications; limited auditory hit.
abstract: High-control prospective design in extreme-consciousness context with very limited objective target-identification support.

title: Paranormal beliefs and core knowledge confusions: A meta-analysis
citation: Meta-analysis across 25 effects found robust association (r≈0.40) between paranormal belief and ontological confusions.
abstract: Supports cognitive-style pathways that can explain paranormal conviction without requiring real anomalous information transfer.

title: Superstition predicts perception of illusory control
citation: Laboratory contingency task: superstition scores predicted stronger illusion of causality.
abstract: Shows a measurable cognitive mechanism linking superstition with over-attribution of control in random environments.

title: Publication bias is bad for science if not necessarily scientists
citation: Bayesian modeling paper clarifies why publication bias distorts field-level inference even with partially rational readers.
abstract: Metascience analysis reinforcing why weak-effect literatures require strong anti-bias infrastructure.
